department.en: School of Sciense, The University of Tokyo

paper_title.en: Evaluation of expansion coefficients from optimal fitting parameters for the analysis of spectra of diatomic molecules and an application to LiH

description.en: To evaluate individual expansion coefficients composing fitting parameters of the Bom-Oppenheimer corrections to Dunham's coefficients Y-ij that have been given analytically with the Delta (B) and Delta (omega) formalism, we examined the consistency of analytic expressions for those corrections with Watson's assertion of the experimental inseparability of nonadiabatic corrections Q(a,b)(r) for a molecule AB. Derived analytic expressions in terms of optimal fitting parameters for the corrections are essential to evaluate individual expansion coefficients. These expressions also reveal redundancies between empirical correction parameters Delta (ij). A method of evaluating nonadiabatic vibrational corrections Q(a,b)(r) and adiabatic corrections S-a,S-b(r) separately consistent with Watson's assertion of inseparability is presented and is applied to an analysis of spectral data of LiH. Functions Q(a,b) and S-a,S-b for LiH are thus successfully evaluated; S-H,S-Li(r) values agree well with those predicted simply by wobble-stretch theory. Experimental values for optimal fitting parameters r(1q)(H), and r(2q)(H) are nearly equal to those of r(1q)(Li) and r(2q)(Li), respectively, in agreement with a theoretical relation r(iq)(a) = r(jq)(b). (C) 2001 Academic Press.

paper_title.en: Analysis of the infrared spectrum of RbCl vapor

description.en: With laser diodes we measured spectra of RbCl vapor near 1000 K in absorption in a region 43800-46400 m(-1) and assigned vibration-rotational transitions, 226 of (RbCl)-Rb-85-Cl-35 up to v' = 9 and J' = 160, 158 transitions of (RbCl)-Rb-95-Cl-37 and 125 of (RbCl)-Rb-87-Cl-35, all with Delta v = 2. We made a global fit of these 509 new data plus 28 published pure rotational transitions. Of eight evaluated parameters, six are adjusted, pertaining to a function for potential energy, and two are constrained, pertaining to nonadiabatic rotational effects; these parameters suffice to reproduce these data generally within uncertainties of their measurement. Comparison is made with corresponding spectral parameters of HCl, LiCl, NaCl and KCl.

publication_name.en: BULLETIN OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN

paper_title.en: Infrared Spectra of Ge<sup>18</sup>0 and Spectral Parameters of Diatomic Molecules of Compounds of Groups 14 and 16

publication_name.en: Canadian Journal of Analytical Sciences and Spectroscopy

paper_title.en: Dunham treatment including effects of the Born-Oppenheimer breakdown for open-shell diatomic molecules in (2)Sigma states

description.en: A Dunham treatment of an effective Hamiltonian for diatomic molecules in (2)Sigma states that includes contributions of the Born-Oppenheimer breakdown has yielded an expression for vibrational-rotational energy by an expansion in powers of (nu + 1/2)(i) [N(N + l)](j-k)(N'/2)(k), where N' is N for the J = N + 1/2 spin-doublet state and -(N + 1) for the J = N - 1/2 state and k = 0, 1,..., j. Analytic expressions for the expansion coefficients Y-ijk*(upsilon J) provide a potential model appropriate for the spectral fits for molecules in (2)Sigma states. The expansion coefficients Y--(ij0)*(upsilon J) for the k = 0 terms are exactly the same as the Y-ij*(upsilon N) coefficients given for (1)Sigma states, the Dunham coefficients Y-ij modified by the contributions of the Born-Oppenheimer breakdown, provided that a spin contribution originating from off-diagonal electronic corrections of the electronic part of the spin-orbit interaction can be ignored. Spin-rotation energy is given by the terms with coefficients Y-ijk*(upsilon J) (k greater than or equal to 1). There are no Y-ijk*(upsilon J) (k greater than or equal to 2) terms in the previously known methods of analysis for (2)Sigma molecules. The present potential model is applied to the reported vibrational-rotational spectra of CaH and all spectral lines of (CaH)-Ca-40 and (CaD)-Ca-40 isotopomers are fitted to a single set of molecular constants simultaneously with significantly smaller standard deviations. (C) 1998 Academic Press.

paper_title.en: Contribution of the breakdown of the Born-Oppenheimer approximation to higher order Dunham coefficients

description.en: By means of a Delta(w), and Delta(B) formalism for correction parameters, expressions were derived for higher-order Dunham coefficients, Y-04*(upsilon J), Y-12*(upsilon J), and Y (21)*(upsilon J), in which contributions of the breakdown of the Born-Oppenheimer approximation were taken into account. Including Y (04)*(upsilon J), Y (12)*(upsilon J) and Y (21)*(upsilon J), and Dunham's Y-09, Y-17, and Y-25 coefficients in addition to the lower-order Y (ij)*(upsilon J) and Y-k1 in the analysis, an extensive data set of the vibrational-rotational and the rotational transitions for four isotopomers of lithium hydride was fitted simultaneously to a single set of molecular constants within experimental errors. Since lithium hydride is a very light molecule, expressions shown in the present article should provide a means applicable to most cases of the spectral analysis of diatomic molecules in the (1) Sigma state. (C) 1998 Academic Press.

paper_title.en: Analysis of vibration-rotational spectra of KH

description.en: A modified Dunham potential model developed recently was applied to the analysis of vibration-rotational spectra of KH. The spectral data set consisted of 107 lines from the literature and an additional 12 lines measured in the present study. In total 119 spectral lines for four isotopomers were simultaneously fitted to a single set of only 11 molecular parameters, U-omega, U-B, a(1), a(2), a(3), a(4), a(5), Delta(omega)(H), Delta(B)(. H) and Delta(al)(H), well within experimental errors. Values of omega(e)((KH)-K-39) and r(e) within the Born-Oppenheimer approximation are 986.6484(41) cm(-1) and 224.0164(10) pm, respectively, assuming that Delta(omega)(K) and Delta(B)(K) are equal to zero. (C) 1997 Elsevier Science B.V.

paper_title.en: A method of analysis of vibration-rotational and rotational spectra of light diatomic molecules

description.en: The potential model of G. Thompson et al. [J. Mol. Spectrosc. 124, 130-138 (1987)] for an analysis of the vibrational-rotational and the rotational spectra of diatomic molecules is modified by an algebraic WKB treatment of the Schrodinger equation given by Watson's effective Hamiltonian. A compact expression is given for the contributions from the adiabatic and nonadiabatic correction terms in the Hamiltonian to the Dunham's Y-ij coefficients. The present model is applied to the reported vibrational-rotational and rotational spectra of LiH as a typical light diatomic molecule where effects of the diabatic and nonadiabatic corrections are significant, and all spectral lines of all isotopomers are fitted to a single set of molecular constants simultaneously well within experimental errors. The analytical expressions for Delta(omega)(a,b) and Delta(B)(a,b) obtained in the present study provide the basis for the validity of the potential model of Thompson ct al. for molecules composed of heavier atoms. (C) 1997 Academic Press.

paper_title.en: INFRARED DIODE-LASER SPECTROSCOPY OF A HIGH-TEMPERATURE MOLECULE GES USING SPECTRUM PROCESSING BY FOURIER TRANSFORMATION

description.en: The vibrational-rotational spectrum of GeS has been observed using a diode laser spectrometer equipped with a heat-pipe high-temperature cell of a White cell type. Fringes due to optical reflections inside the high-temperature White cell were inherent in the observation of the spectra. However, they were eliminated, as were high-frequency noises, by Fourier manipulation of the observed diode laser spectrum. About 620 spectral lines for the Delta upsilon = 1 band sequences of the eight isotopomers, (GeS)-Ge-74-S-32, (GeS)-Ge-72-S-32, (GeS)-Ge-70-S-32, (GeS)-Ge-73-S-32, (GeS)-Ge-76-S-32, (GeS)-Ge-74-S-34, (GeS)-Ge-72-S-34, and (GeS)-Ge-70-S-34 have been assigned between 522 and 593 cm(-1). These infrared data combined with 91 microwave data from the literature have been analyzed with a least-squares fit to a Dunham potential function with only 11 parameters which included three Watson type Delta correction terms. The Dunham Y-ij coefficients have been derived for each of the eight isotopomers. The equilibrium vibrational frequency omega(e), of (GeS)-Ge-74-S-32 is 574.269 313(271) cm(-1).

paper_title.en: Vibration-Rotational Spectra of GaF and Molecular Properties of Diatomic Fluorides of Elements in Group 13 (共著)

publication_name.en: Journal of the Chemical Society Faraday Transactions

paper_title.en: Infrared Diode Laser Spectroscopy of a High-Temperature Molecule : GeSe(共著)
ANALYSIS OF INFRARED-SPECTRA OF GASEOUS TIF

description.en: Vibration-rotational spectra of (TlF)-Tl-205-F-19 and (TlF)-Tl-203-F-19 in the electronic ground state X0(+) were measured in absorption in the range of wave number 44 900 less than or equal to nu ($) over tilde/m(-1) less than or equal to 50 000 with diode lasers as spectral sources. Analysis of all available data yielded values of coefficients of radial functions for the potential energy and other molecular properties; only eight independently fitted and two constrained parameters sufficed to reproduce satisfactorily and with physical meaning the frequencies and wave numbers of about 890 distinct pure rotational and vibration-rotational transitions. Independent of nuclear mass, the equilibrium internuclear separation R(e) of TlF is (2.084 3517 +/- 0.000 0039) x 10(-10) m; the maximum range of validity of radial functions is 1.85 less than or equal to R/10(-10) m less than or equal to 2.45. Comparing these results with those of InF, we attribute the large magnitude of u(l)(Tl) to the finite and isotopically varying nuclear volume of Tl rather than to (adiabatic) effects of nuclear mass, whereas no such effect is detectable for In in InF. Other aspects of nonadiabatic effects for these polar molecules TlF and InF are discussed.

paper_title.en: THE HIGH-RESOLUTION INFRARED-SPECTRUM OF BRCL

description.en: The high-resolution infrared spectrum of Br Cl has been observed with a Fourier transform spectrometer. About 850 spectral lines for the Delta v = 1 sequences of the four isotopic species, (BrCl)-Br-79-Cl-35, (BrCl)-Br-81-Cl-35, (BrCl)-Br-79-Cl-37, and (BrCl)-Br-81-Cl-37 have been measured between 417 and 461 cm(-1). They have been fitted with a standard deviation of 0.000 146 cm(-1) to a Dunham potential function using eight coefficients that included two Watson-type Delta correction terms. Dunham Y-ij coefficients have been derived for each of the four isotopic species. The equilibrium internuclear distance r(e) of BrCl is 2.136 053 28 (67) Angstrom.

paper_title.en: Infrared Diode Laser Spectroscopy of the Δv=2 Band of NaBr Using Spectrum Processing by Fourier Transformation
INFRARED DIODE-LASER SPECTROSCOPY OF HIGH-TEMPERATURE MOLECULES USING SPECTRUM PROCESSING BY FOURIER TRANSFORMATION

description.en: A heat-pipe high-temperature cell of the White cell type was constructed for sensitive detection of the spectra of high-temperature molecules. It has been incorporated into the optical system of a tunable diode laser spectrometer. With a 40 m optical path length abundant spectral lines of the DELTAupsilon=2 vibration-rotation bands of NaBr have been observed in the wavenumber range between 560 and 600 cm-1. The technique of spectrum processing by use of Fourier transformation was applied to the source-modulated diode laser spectrum to eliminate fringes and to improve the signal-to-noise ratio.

paper_title.en: INFRARED-EMISSION SPECTRUM OF ALBR

description.en: An infrared emission spectrum of the DELTAv = 1 bands of AlBr has been observed with a Fourier transform spectrometer with 0.1 cm-1 resolution. The v = 1-0 to 3-2 and v = 5-4 vibration-rotation bands of (AlBr)-Br-79 and the v = 1-0 to 5-4 bands of (AlBr)-Br-81 were assigned in the wavenumber range between 310 and 400 cm-1. The infrared data combined with millimeter-wave data from the literature were analyzed with a least-squares fit to a Dunham potential function with only seven parameters. Thirteen Dunham Y(ij) coefficients have been derived for each of the isotopic species.

paper_title.en: INFRARED-EMISSION SPECTRUM OF NABR

description.en: The infrared emission spectrum of DELTAupsilon = 1 bands of NaBr monomer has been observed with a Fourier transform spectrometer. The upsilon = 1-0 to 5-4 vibration-rotation bands for both (NaBr)-Br-79 and (NaBr)-Br-81 were assigned in the wavenumber range between 225 and 315 cm-1. These infrared data combined with millimeter-wave data from the literature were analyzed with a least-squares fit to a Dunham potential function with only seven parameters. Omega(e)((NaBr)-Br-79) has been determined to be 298.7377(43) cm-1 with one standard error in parentheses. Thirteen Dunham Y(ij) coefficients have been derived for each of the two isotopic species from the Dunham potential function.

paper_title.en: Infrared Diode Laser Spectroscopy of InF
INFRARED-EMISSION SPECTRUM OF TLF

description.en: The infrared emission spectrum of DELTA-upsilon = 1 bands of TlF has been observed. The upsilon = 1-0 to 6-5 vibration-rotation bands of (TlF)-Tl-205 and the upsilon = 1-0 to 4.3 bands of (TlF)-Tl-203 were assigned in wavenumber range between 380 and 500 cm-1. The analysis has led to a set of values of eight Dunham coefficients, Y10, Y20, Y30, Y40, Y01, Y11, Y21 and Y02, of (TlF)-Tl-205. Y10 and Y20 were determined to be 476.947(12) and -2.2445(71) cm-1, respectively, with twice the standard errors in parentheses. The infrared diode-laser spectrum of TlF has also been observed and the assignment of some spectral lines is shown.

paper_title.en: INFRARED-EMISSION SPECTRUM OF GAF

description.en: The infrared emission spectrum of DELTA-upsilon = 1 bands of GaF has been observed at 1000-degrees-C with a resolution of 0.1 cm-1. The upsilon = 1-0 to 5-4 vibration-rotation bands of 69GaF and the upsilon = 1-0 to 4-3 bands of 71GaF were assigned in the wavenumber range between 500 and 645 cm-1. The analysis has led to a set of values of eight Dunham coefficients, Y10, Y20, Y30, Y01, Y11, Y21, Y02 and Y12 of 69GaF. Y10 and Y20 were determined to be 622.367(11) and -3.3049(42) cm-1, respectively, with twice the standard errors in parentheses. The infrared diode- laser spectrum of GaF has also been observed and the assignment of some spectral lines is shown.
